conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to determine the magnitude and direction of the frictional force acting on the wire frame at t = 2.5 seconds.
Calculate the magnetic flux through the wire frame as a function of time.
Determine the induced emf in the wire frame using Faraday's law.
Find the induced current in the wire frame.
Calculate the magnetic force on the wire frame.
Determine the frictional force required to keep the wire frame stationary.
The magnetic field B is given by B(t) = (3 + 2t) T.
The area A of the wire frame is A = (0.2 m)^2 = 0.04 m^2.
Since only half of the wire frame is in the magnetic field, the effective area A_eff is A_eff = 0.02 m^2.
The magnetic flux Φ(t) through the wire frame is Φ(t) = (0.06 + 0.04t) Wb.
Differentiate Φ(t) with respect to t to get dΦ/dt = 0.04 V.
The induced emf is E = -0.04 V.
The induced current I in the wire frame is I = -0.01 A.
At t = 2.5 seconds, the magnetic field B is B(2.5) = 8 T.
The length L of the side of the wire frame in the magnetic field is 0.2 m.
The force on one side of the wire frame is F_B = -0.016 N.
The total magnetic force is F_total = -0.032 N.
